mentions.context: Spark is designed to support the execution of iterative algorithms [21].
To execute a Spark job, we need a master node to coordinate job execution, and some worker nodes to execute a parallel operation.
Similar to MapReduce [36], Spark can be deployed on the Hadoop Distributed File System (HDFS) [37].

Unlike traditional in-memory systems, the main feature of Spark is its distributed memory abstraction, called resilient distributed datasets (RDD), that is an efficient and fault-tolerant abstraction for distributing data in a cluster.
We used an implementation available at Spark's machine learning library (MLlib) [42].
It takes advantage of the computing power of distributed systems by using parallel frameworks such as Spark [21].
The parallel experimental evaluation was conducted on a computing cluster of 32 machines, each operated by Linux, with 64 Gigabytes of main memory, Intel Xeon CPU with

For this reason, we aim to implement a parallel algorithm for DPM clustering in a massively distributed environment called Spark which is a parallel programming framework aiming to efficiently process large datasets.

These parallel operations are summarized to two types: (i) Transformations: to create a new RDD from an existing one (e.g., Map, MapToPair, MapPartition, FlatMap); and (ii) Actions: to return a final value to the user (e.g., Reduce, Aggregate or Count) [21].
